document_title: Coronary artery stenosis: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
Your doctor will diagnose whether you have coronary artery stenosis or not through a general physical examination and performing paraclinical tests.
During the physical examination, the doctor will: (4)
Blood pressure; Listen to the heartbeat; Ask how long your symptoms have been present; Ask about your medical history, lifestyle and diet; Ask about your family history and see if anyone had cardiovascular disease when they were young
Clinical tests help diagnose coronary artery disease:
Blood test: to check if there are substances that are harmful to the arteries or increase the risk of coronary artery stenosis; Cardiac catheterization: The doctor inserts a catheter into the coronary artery to diagnose coronary artery disease as well as determine the degree of narrowing.; Coronary computed tomography (MSCT): to see 3D images of the heart, detect blockages in the coronary arteries.; Coronary calcium angiogram: measures the amount of calcium in the coronary artery walls (a sign of atherosclerosis).; This method does not detect blockages but helps identify risk factors for coronary artery disease.; Echocardiography: Uses sound waves to evaluate the structure and function of the heart.; Electrocardiogram (EKG/ECG): records the electrical activity of the heart, helping to detect old or current myocardial infarctions, ischemia as well as heart rhythm problems.; Stress testing exercise: see how the heart reacts when it is working very hard. This exercise can detect angina and blockages in the coronary arteries.
Coronary angiography is one of the methods to help detect coronary artery stenosis
